bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lucy T. Howard, August 17, 1946

div1.p: Hench is trying to locate correspondence between L.O. Howard and the yellow fever investigators at various U.S. government agencies. He inquires if Lucy Howard has any of her father's papers at the family home.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lucy T. Howard, August 17, 1946
div1.opener:
August 17, 1946
Miss Lucy Howard
Onteora Club
Tannersville, New York
My dear Miss Howard:
div1.p:
After visiting you and your father in May, I was in Washington
and did as you suggested. I got in touch with Miss Mabel Colcord, who
told me that she had sorted out all of your father's personal correspondence
and had sent it to him. The rest had been sent from the Bureau of
Entomology to the National Archives. To make certain about this, I talked
to Mrs. Maud Miller, the chief mail and file room clerk at the Bureau of
Entomology. She spent a day trying to locate any further correspondence
between your father and the yellow fever personalities, chiefly Doctors
Reed, Carroll, and Lazear. She was unable to find anything and assured
me that all of the material not given to Doctor Howard had been sent
to the National Archives. I then visited the National Archives, showed
them what correspondence I had copies of and asked Mr. Herman Kahn, the
Chief of the Division of the Interior Department of the Archives, for
his assistance. They apparently spent sometime hunting for further
correspondence on your father. They finally uncovered about twelve more
letters, copies of which I did not have--letters between your father
and Carroll, between your father and Doctor Reed. They found no letters
between your father and Doctor Lazear.

You will remember that some of the correspondence of your
father mentioned additional letters between himself and the above
mentioned party. In particular your father published one of those letters
from Walter Reed and it would appear that somewhere in his personal
effects there must be the remains of this correspondence.

I hate, indeed, to bother you, but you were kind enough to
suggest that you might be able to find time to locate a box or a trunk
of your fathers which might have in it the missing data, and I believe
this material you thought might be in Tannersville. I do hope that
this material will eventually turn up. It is of considerable importance
to show not only the relationship of your father to the conquest of
yellow fever, but also to show the early interest of Doctors Reed and
Lazear in learning about mosquitoes. Being the daughter of a famous
father, unfortunately, carries certain responsibilities and obligations,
doesn't it?

You and your father were very kind, indeed, to me. I
thoroughly enjoyed my visit. I only wish that I could have the opportunity
Miss Lucy Howard
-2-
August 17, 1946
of examining your father's data without bothering you unduly. I
apologize sincerely for bothering you further, but I don't know to
whom else to turn. Were you planning on bringing this material back
to New York? I expect to visit Washington this fall, and if you think
it necessary or helpful, I would be delighted to run over to New York
to help go through this material so as to give you as little trouble
as possible.

In July, I attended the meeting of the American Medical
Association in San Francisco and thereafter visited Doctor Lazear's
son in Santa Barbara. He knew very little about his father's work.
Because of a tragic misunderstanding on the part of Mrs. Lazear, the
children had been raised in almost complete ignorance of their father's
work. It was a real pleasure to tell him the true story. I don't
believe I ever sent you or your father a copy of an article that I
wrote sometime ago on the yellow fever story. Permit me to send it to
you by separate post. Please give my very kindest regards to your
father.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
